clinical_description: Atrial fibrillation (AFib) is an irregular and often very rapid heart rhythm. An irregular heart rhythm is called an arrhythmia. AFib can lead to blood clots in the heart. The condition also increases the risk of stroke, heart failure and other heart-related complications. During atrial fibrillation, the heart's upper chambers — called the atria — beat chaotically and irregularly. They beat out of sync with the lower heart chambers, called the ventricles. For many people, AFib may have no symptoms. But AFib may cause a fast, pounding heartbeat, shortness of breath or light-headedness. Episodes of atrial fibrillation may come and go, or they may be persistent. AFib itself usually isn't life-threatening. But it's a serious medical condition that needs proper treatment to prevent stroke. Treatment for atrial fibrillation may include medicines, therapy to shock the heart back to a regular rhythm and procedures to block faulty heart signals. A person with atrial fibrillation also may have a related heart rhythm problem called atrial flutter. The treatments for AFib and atrial flutter are similar.
simplified_explanation:
Atrial fibrillation (AFib) is a condition where the heart beats in an uneven and often very fast way. It happens when the upper parts of the heart beat out of sync with the lower parts, making the heartbeat feel jumpy or irregular. This can cause blood clots to form, which may lead to a stroke — when blood flow to the brain is blocked.
Some people don’t feel any symptoms, but others might notice a racing heart, shortness of breath, or dizziness.
AFib can come and go or last a long time. Even though it isn’t always dangerous by itself, it needs treatment to avoid serious problems. Doctors might use medicine, electric shocks, or special procedures to help the heart beat normally again.
plain_explanation: Atrial fibrillation (AFib) is when your heart beats very quickly and irregularly.
symptoms:
- Fast, pounding heartbeat
- Shortness of breath
- Light-headedness or dizziness
- Chest pain or discomfort
- Difficulty sleeping or insomnia

Term: epilepsy
Description: Epilepsy is a neurological disorder in which the brain has repeated seizures. Seizures can affect different parts of the body. They can cause physical symptoms such as shaking, loss of consciousness, confusion, or difficulty speaking or moving. Seizures can also cause emotional or mental symptoms such as anxiety or panic. The exact cause of epilepsy is often unknown, but it can be triggered by certain medications, infections, trauma to the head, or a family history of epilepsy. Some people with epilepsy have no symptoms between seizures, while others have frequent seizures. Epilepsy is not contagious, and it is not a sign of weakness. It is a medical condition that needs proper treatment. Treatment for epilepsy may include medications, therapy, lifestyle changes, or surgery.

clinical_description: An aneurysm is a bulge or ballooning in the wall of a blood vessel. An aneurysm can break open. This is called a rupture. A ruptured aneurysm causes bleeding inside the body. It often leads to death. Some aneurysms cause no symptoms. You might not know you have an aneurysm even if it is large. Aneurysms can form in several parts of the body, including: The body's main artery, called the aorta (aortic aneurysm). The part of the aorta that passes through the belly area (abdominal aortic aneurysm). The part of the aorta that passes through the chest (thoracic aortic aneurysm). Blood vessels that send blood to the brain (brain aneurysm). Blood vessels in other parts of the body, such as the legs, groin or neck (peripheral aneurysm). Some small aneurysms have a low risk of rupture. To determine the risk of an aneurysm rupture, a healthcare professional considers: Your symptoms. Your medical history. Your family's medical history. The size, shape and location of the aneurysm. Some people with aneurysms only need regular health checkups and imaging tests. If an aneurysm breaks open, emergency treatment is needed. Treatment may involve open surgery or a less-invasive treatment called endovascular surgery.
simplified_explanation:
An aneurysm is a bulge or balloon-like area in a blood vessel. It can happen in different parts of the body, like the brain, chest, belly, or legs. If the aneurysm gets too big, it can burst and cause serious bleeding inside the body.
Some people don’t feel anything, even if the aneurysm is large. But if it bursts, it’s a medical emergency.
Doctors decide how risky it is based on its size, shape, and where it is in the body. Some aneurysms just need regular checkups, but others may need surgery or a less invasive procedure to fix them before they break open.
plain_explanation: An aneurysm is a bulge or ballooning in the wall of a blood vessel. It can cause bleeding inside the body.
symptoms:
- Severe headache
- Dizziness
- Blurry vision or loss of vision
- Loss of control of body movements (paralysis)

clinical_description: Bell's palsy is a condition that causes sudden weakness in the muscles on one side of the face. Often the weakness is short-term and improves over weeks. The weakness makes half of the face appear to droop. Smiles are one-sided, and the eye on the affected side is hard to close. Bell's palsy also is known as acute peripheral facial palsy of unknown cause. It can occur at any age. The exact cause is not known. Experts think it's caused by swelling and irritation of the nerve that controls the muscles on one side of the face. Bell's palsy could be caused by a reaction that occurs after a viral infection. Symptoms usually start to improve within a few weeks, with complete recovery in about six months. A small number of people continue to have some Bell's palsy symptoms for life. Rarely, Bell's palsy occurs more than once.
simplified_explanation:
Bell’s palsy causes sudden weakness on one side of the face. This can make half of the face look droopy, and it might be hard to smile or close one eye.
Doctors think it happens when a nerve in the face gets swollen, often after a virus.
It can happen at any age and usually gets better on its own in a few weeks or months. Some people recover completely, while others may have small, lasting effects. In rare cases, it can happen more than once.
plain_explanation:
---

 Bell's palsy is when one side of your face gets weak and can't move properly. It's like your face is half paralyzed.
symptoms:
- The muscles on one side of your face droop, making your smile one-sided.
- Your eye on the affected side is hard to close.
- Your mouth might be dry or your tongue might feel weak.
- It might be hard to eat or talk because of the weakness on one side.

clinical_description: Bronchitis is an inflammation of the lining of your bronchial tubes. These tubes carry air to and from your lungs. People who have bronchitis often cough up thickened mucus, which can be discolored. Bronchitis may start suddenly and be short term (acute) or start gradually and become long term (chronic). Acute bronchitis, which often develops from a cold or other respiratory infection, is very common. Also called a chest cold, acute bronchitis usually improves within a week to 10 days without lasting effects, although the cough may linger for weeks. Chronic bronchitis, a more serious condition, is a constant irritation or inflammation of the lining of the bronchial tubes, often due to smoking. If you have repeated bouts of bronchitis, you may have chronic bronchitis, which requires medical attention. Chronic bronchitis is one of the conditions included in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
simplified_explanation:
Bronchitis is when the tubes that carry air to and from your lungs get swollen and irritated. This makes it harder to breathe and often causes a cough with thick mucus. It can be short-term (called acute bronchitis), which usually comes from a cold and gets better in about a week — though the cough may last longer.
Chronic bronchitis is more serious and lasts a long time. It’s often caused by smoking and can make breathing harder over time. People with repeated bronchitis may have a condition called COPD. Treatment depends on the type, but rest, fluids, and avoiding smoke can help.
plain_explanation: Bronchitis is when your breathing tubes (called bronchial tubes) get inflamed. This is like when your eyes get red and itchy from a cold, except it's your breathing tubes.
symptoms:
- Coughing up thick mucus (phlegm) that may be green, yellow, or white
- Wheezing (a high-pitched noise when you breathe in or out)
- Shortness of breath (feeling like you can't catch your breath)
- Chest tightness or pain

It's important to see a doctor if you have symptoms of bronchitis, especially if they last more than a week, because chronic bronchitis can lead to serious health problems if left untreated.

clinical_description: Calciphylaxis (kal-sih-fuh-LAK-sis) is a rare, serious disease. It involves a buildup of calcium in small blood vessels of fat tissues and skin. Calciphylaxis symptoms include blood clots, lumps under the skin and painful open sores called ulcers. If an ulcer becomes infected, it can be life-threatening. The exact cause of calciphylaxis isn't clear. But people with the disease usually have kidney failure. That's a condition in which the kidneys no longer work as they should. Often, these same people also have received kidney failure treatments such as dialysis or a kidney transplant. Calciphylaxis can happen in people without kidney disease too. Calciphylaxis treatments include various medicines, procedures and surgery. Treatment can help prevent blood clots and infections, reduce calcium buildups, heal sores, and ease pain.
simplified_explanation:
Calciphylaxis is a rare and serious condition where calcium builds up in small blood vessels in the skin and fat. This can lead to painful lumps or open sores that may become infected. It’s most common in people with kidney failure, especially those on dialysis, but it can happen in others too.
The cause isn’t fully known. If not treated, it can be life-threatening. Treatments focus on reducing calcium buildup, healing sores, and preventing infection. Medicine, wound care, and sometimes surgery are used to manage the condition.
plain_explanation: Calciphylaxis is when too much calcium gets into the fat tissues and skin. It can cause problems like blood clots and open sores.
symptoms:
- Blood clots
- Lumps under the skin
- Painful open sores called ulcers

Term: fibromyalgia
Description: Fibromyalgia (fih-bo-mih-AL-gee-uh) is a chronic pain disease. It affects mostly women. People with fibromyalgia feel pain and fatigue all over their bodies. They may also have trouble sleeping, headaches, and digestive problems. Fibromyalgia can be hard to diagnose because symptoms can overlap with other conditions. But fibromyalgia is treatable. Treatment may include pain medication, therapy, lifestyle changes, and exercise.

Plain Explanation: Fibromyalgia is when someone has a lot of pain all over their body.

Symptoms:
- Pain all over the body
- Fatigue (feeling tired a lot)

clinical_description: A cataract is a clouding of the lens of the eye, which is typically clear. For people who have cataracts, seeing through cloudy lenses is like looking through a frosty or fogged-up window. Clouded vision caused by cataracts can make it more difficult to read, drive a car at night or see the expression on a friend's face. Most cataracts develop slowly and don't disturb eyesight early on. But with time, cataracts will eventually affect vision. At first, stronger lighting and eyeglasses can help deal with cataracts. But if impaired vision affects usual activities, cataract surgery might be needed. Fortunately, cataract surgery is generally a safe, effective procedure.
simplified_explanation:
A cataract is when the clear lens in your eye becomes cloudy, like looking through a foggy window. This can make it harder to read, drive at night, or see faces clearly. Cataracts often develop slowly and may not affect your vision at first.
In the early stages, brighter lights or new glasses might help. But if your vision gets worse and affects daily life, surgery may be needed. Cataract surgery is common and usually safe, and it replaces the cloudy lens with a clear one.
plain_explanation:
---

 A cataract is when the lens in your eye gets cloudy and it's harder to see. Think of it like a foggy window on a car - it's harder to see through.
symptoms:
- It's harder to see at night
- Things look blurry and out of focus
- Colors appear dull or muted
- You have double vision

Term: asthma
Description: Asthma is a lung condition that causes your airways to narrow. When you have asthma, it's harder to breathe and you might have a cough, wheezing, and shortness of breath. Asthma is usually controlled with medicine that you take regularly. But sometimes, asthma can be worse than usual and it's called an asthma attack or exacerbation. During an asthma attack, it's important to have a rescue inhaler to help you breathe better. Asthma can be scary, but with the right medicine and care, people with asthma can live healthy, active lives.

clinical_description: Diabetes mellitus refers to a group of diseases that affect how the body uses blood sugar (glucose). Glucose is an important source of energy for the cells that make up the muscles and tissues. It's also the brain's main source of fuel. The main cause of diabetes varies by type. But no matter what type of diabetes you have, it can lead to excess sugar in the blood. Too much sugar in the blood can lead to serious health problems. Chronic diabetes conditions include type 1 diabetes and type 2 diabetes. Potentially reversible diabetes conditions include prediabetes and gestational diabetes. Prediabetes happens when blood sugar levels are higher than normal. But the blood sugar levels aren't high enough to be called diabetes. And prediabetes can lead to diabetes unless steps are taken to prevent it. Gestational diabetes happens during pregnancy. But it may go away after the baby is born.
simplified_explanation:
Diabetes is a group of conditions that affect how your body uses blood sugar (glucose). Glucose is your body’s main source of energy, especially for the muscles and brain. In diabetes, sugar builds up in the blood because the body doesn’t make or use insulin properly.
There are different types: type 1, type 2, and gestational diabetes (during pregnancy). Some cases, like prediabetes, can be reversed with healthy changes. If left untreated, diabetes can cause serious problems like heart disease or kidney damage. Treatment usually includes a healthy diet, exercise, and sometimes medication or insulin.
plain_explanation: Diabetes is a health condition where the body doesn't use sugar properly. Sugar is important for energy, but when there's too much sugar in the body, it can cause serious problems. There are two main types of diabetes: type 1 and type 2. Sometimes, you can have a type of diabetes that might be reversible, like prediabetes or gestational diabetes.
symptoms:
- Frequent urination: You may need to pee more often than normal.
- Increased thirst: You may feel more thirsty than usual.
- Blurry vision: You may see things that are blurry or out of focus.
- Fatigue: You may feel tired or weak more often than usual.

clinical_description: Dysarthria happens when the muscles used for speech are weak or are hard to control. Dysarthria often causes slurred or slow speech that can be difficult to understand. Common causes of dysarthria include conditions that affect the nervous system or that cause facial paralysis. These conditions may cause tongue or throat muscle weakness. Certain medicines also can cause dysarthria. Treating the underlying cause of dysarthria may improve your speech. You also may need speech therapy. For dysarthria caused by prescription medicines, changing or stopping the medicines may help.
simplified_explanation:
Dysarthria is a speech problem that happens when the muscles used for talking are weak or hard to control. It can cause speech to sound slurred, slow, or hard to understand. It’s often caused by nerve or brain conditions, or sometimes by certain medications.
Getting treatment for the cause may help speech improve. Many people also benefit from speech therapy. If medicine is the reason, changing the medication may help.
plain_explanation: Dysarthria means that your muscles for talking are not working well. It can make you sound like you're talking slow and slurred. There are many reasons why this can happen. It might be because of a problem with your nerves or your face being paralyzed. Some medicines can also cause this. But, if you get the right treatment, it can help!
symptoms:
- Your words might sound strange or slurred.
- You may have a hard time talking clearly.
- You might drool or have trouble swallowing.
- Your voice might sound quiet or hoarse.

clinical_description: Ectropion (ek-TROH-pee-on) is a condition in which your eyelid turns outward. This leaves the inner eyelid surface exposed and prone to irritation. Ectropion is more common in older adults, and it generally affects only the lower eyelid. In severe ectropion, the entire length of the eyelid is turned out. In less severe ectropion, only one segment of the eyelid sags away from the eye. Artificial tears and lubricating ointments can help relieve symptoms of ectropion. But usually surgery is needed to fully correct the condition.
simplified_explanation:
Ectropion is a condition where the lower eyelid turns outward, leaving the inner part of the eyelid exposed. This can cause dryness, irritation, or watery eyes because the eye isn’t fully protected. It mostly affects older adults and usually only happens in one eye.
In mild cases, just a small part of the eyelid droops. In severe cases, the whole lower eyelid may turn out.
Eye drops and ointments can help with symptoms, but surgery is usually needed to fix the eyelid and protect the eye.

clinical_description: Endocarditis is a life-threatening inflammation of the inner lining of the heart's chambers and valves. This lining is called the endocardium. Endocarditis is usually caused by an infection. Bacteria, fungi or other germs get into the bloodstream and attach to damaged areas in the heart. Things that make you more likely to get endocarditis are artificial heart valves, damaged heart valves or other heart defects. Without quick treatment, endocarditis can damage or destroy the heart valves. Treatments for endocarditis include medications and surgery. Endocarditis occurs when bacteria or other germs enter the bloodstream and travel to the heart. The germs then stick to damaged heart valves or damaged heart tissue.
simplified_explanation:
Endocarditis is a serious infection of the inside lining of the heart and its valves. It happens when bacteria or other germs get into the bloodstream and stick to damaged areas in the heart. People with artificial or damaged heart valves are at higher risk.
If not treated quickly, endocarditis can destroy the heart valves and become life-threatening.
Treatment usually includes strong antibiotics and sometimes surgery. Catching and treating it early can help prevent major heart damage.
plain_explanation: Endocarditis is a dangerous condition that happens when the lining inside your heart gets swollen and inflamed. It's usually caused by an infection that gets into your bloodstream.
symptoms:
- Fever
- Fatigue (feeling tired)
- Shortness of breath (not being able to breathe easily)
- Swelling in your ankles, feet, or legs
- Rapid or irregular heartbeat

clinical_description: Fibromyalgia is a long-term condition that involves widespread body pain. The pain happens along with fatigue. It also can involve issues with sleep, memory and mood. Researchers think that fibromyalgia affects the way the brain and spinal cord process painful and nonpainful signals. That increases your overall sensitivity to pain. Symptoms often start after a triggering event. Triggers can include injuries, surgery, infections or emotional stress. Or the symptoms can build up over time, with no single event to trigger them. Women are more likely to get fibromyalgia than are men. Many people who have fibromyalgia also have: Headaches. Jaw and facial pain due to temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorders. Irritable bowel syndrome. Anxiety. Depression. There's no cure for fibromyalgia. But medicines and other treatments can help control the symptoms. Exercise, talk therapy and techniques that lower stress also may help.
simplified_explanation:
Fibromyalgia is a long-term condition that causes widespread pain all over the body. It often comes with fatigue, sleep problems, and issues with memory or mood. Experts believe it affects how the brain and spinal cord process pain signals, making you more sensitive to pain.
Symptoms can start after a physical or emotional event, or they may appear slowly over time.
Fibromyalgia is more common in women and often comes with other problems like headaches, jaw pain, stomach issues, anxiety, or depression.
There’s no cure, but medicine, gentle exercise, therapy, and stress-reduction techniques can help manage symptoms.
plain_explanation: Fibromyalgia is when you feel pain all over your body and it's hard to sleep. It also makes you feel tired. People don't know exactly why it happens, but it might be because of an injury or stress.
symptoms:
- Pain all over your body.
- Trouble sleeping.
- Feeling tired all the time.
- Headaches.
- Jaw and face pain.

clinical_description: Folliculitis is a common skin condition that happens when hair follicles become inflamed. It's often caused by an infection with bacteria. At first it may look like small pimples around the tiny pockets from where each hair grows (hair follicles). The condition can be itchy, sore and embarrassing. The infection can spread and turn into crusty sores. Mild folliculitis will likely heal without scarring in a few days with basic self-care. More-serious or repeat infections may need prescription medicine. Left untreated, severe infections can cause permanent hair loss and scarring. Certain types of folliculitis are known as hot tub rash and barber's itch.
simplified_explanation:
Folliculitis is a skin condition where the hair follicles get inflamed, usually from a bacterial infection. It can look like small pimples around the base of hairs and may be itchy or painful.
In mild cases, it goes away in a few days with basic care, like cleaning the area and avoiding shaving or tight clothing.
More serious or repeat infections may need prescription creams or pills. If left untreated, it can lead to scars or permanent hair loss.
There are special names for certain types, like “hot tub rash” or “barber’s itch.”
plain_explanation: Folliculitis is when your hair follicles get inflamed and it looks like little pimples on your skin.
symptoms:
- Itchy skin around the pimples
- Sore or painful spots on your skin
- Red or yellow pimples
- Crusty sores that may smell bad

Remember, if your folliculitis doesn't go away or it gets worse, you should talk to your doctor because they might need to give you medicine to help it heal.

clinical_description: Gallstones are hardened deposits of digestive fluid that can form in your gallbladder. Your gallbladder is a small, pear-shaped organ on the right side of your abdomen, just beneath your liver. The gallbladder holds a digestive fluid called bile that's released into your small intestine. Gallstones range in size from as small as a grain of sand to as large as a golf ball. Some people develop just one gallstone, while others develop many gallstones at the same time. People who experience symptoms from their gallstones usually require gallbladder removal surgery. Gallstones that don't cause any signs and symptoms typically don't need treatment.
simplified_explanation:
Gallstones are hard lumps that form in the gallbladder, a small organ under your liver that helps with digestion. They’re made from digestive fluids and can be as small as a grain of sand or as big as a golf ball.
Some people have just one gallstone, while others have many. Most people don’t feel anything, but if a gallstone blocks a bile duct, it can cause pain, nausea, or digestive problems.
If gallstones cause symptoms, the usual treatment is to remove the gallbladder with surgery. If there are no symptoms, treatment might not be needed.
plain_explanation: Gallstones are like small, hard stones that can form in your gallbladder. A gallbladder is a small organ that sits near your liver and helps digest food. Bile is a fluid that helps digest food and is stored in the gallbladder. Sometimes, bile can harden into stones. These stones can be small or large, and some people get many of them at once. If the stones cause problems, they might need to be removed with surgery. But if they don't cause any issues, they don't usually need treatment.
symptoms:
- Abdominal pain: This is often the most common symptom of gallstones. It can feel sharp or dull and can happen in the upper right side of your abdomen.
- Nausea and vomiting: This can happen when the gallstones block the ducts that carry bile to your small intestine.
- Diarrhea: This can also happen when the gallstones block the ducts and cause bile to back up in your gallbladder.
- Fever: In some cases, gallstones can cause a fever, especially if they're infected.

clinical_description: Glaucoma is an eye condition that damages the optic nerve. This damage can lead to vision loss or blindness. The optic nerve sends visual information from your eye to the brain and is vital for good vision. Damage to the optic nerve is often related to high pressure in the eye. But glaucoma can happen even with typical eye pressure. Glaucoma can happen at any age but is more common in older adults. It is one of the leading causes of blindness for people over the age of 60. Many forms of glaucoma have no warning signs. The effect is so gradual that you may not notice a change in vision until the condition is in its later stages. It's important to have regular eye exams that include measurements of your eye pressure. If glaucoma is found early, vision loss can be slowed or prevented. If you have glaucoma, you'll need treatment or monitoring for the rest of your life.
simplified_explanation:
Glaucoma is an eye disease that damages the optic nerve, which carries signals from your eyes to your brain. This damage can lead to vision loss or blindness, especially if it’s not caught early. It’s often caused by high pressure inside the eye, but not always.
Glaucoma is more common in older adults, and many people don’t notice symptoms until the disease is advanced. That’s why regular eye exams are important — they can help catch it before vision is lost.
If caught early, treatment can slow or prevent vision loss. Most people with glaucoma need ongoing treatment or monitoring for life.
plain_explanation: Glaucoma is a health problem with the eyes that can cause blindness. This happens when the nerve that helps us see gets damaged. It's like a road that helps us get where we need to go, but if it's broken, we can't get there. The damage usually happens because of high pressure in the eye. But sometimes, it can happen even when the pressure is normal. Glaucoma happens more often when we get older. It's a big cause of blindness for people over 60. Sometimes, there are no warning signs. It's important to get checked regularly by a doctor who will check the pressure in your eyes. If we find glaucoma early, we can try to stop or slow down the damage so we don't lose our vision. If you have glaucoma, you'll need to keep getting checked and possibly get treatment or monitoring to keep your eyes healthy.

clinical_description: Hashimoto's disease is an autoimmune disorder affecting the thyroid gland. The thyroid is a butterfly-shaped gland located at the base of the neck just below the Adam's apple. The thyroid produces hormones that help regulate many functions in the body. An autoimmune disorder is an illness caused by the immune system attacking healthy tissues. In Hashimoto's disease, immune-system cells lead to the death of the thyroid's hormone-producing cells. The disease usually results in a decline in hormone production (hypothyroidism). Although anyone can develop Hashimoto's disease, it's most common among middle-aged women. The primary treatment is thyroid hormone replacement. Hashimoto's disease is also known as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis and chronic autoimmune thyroiditis.
simplified_explanation:
Hashimoto’s disease is an autoimmune condition that affects the thyroid, a gland in the neck that helps control energy and other body functions. In this disease, the immune system attacks the thyroid, causing it to stop making enough hormones — a condition called hypothyroidism.
This can lead to tiredness, weight gain, feeling cold, and other symptoms. Hashimoto’s is most common in middle-aged women, but it can affect anyone.
There’s no cure, but it’s treatable with thyroid hormone pills, which help the body work normally again.
plain_explanation: Hashimoto's disease is when your body's immune system attacks and kills the cells that make the thyroid hormones. The thyroid gland is like a butterfly-shaped gland in your neck that makes these hormones. These hormones are super important for our bodies to work normally. A lot of people get Hashimoto's disease when they are older. The good news is that we can take medicine to replace the hormones the thyroid makes.
symptoms:
- You might feel tired or weak all the time.
- You might have trouble losing weight.
- You might feel cold when it's not that cold outside.
- You might feel like your skin is dry and flaky.

clinical_description: Heartburn is a burning pain in your chest, just behind your breastbone. The pain is often worse after eating, in the evening, or when lying down or bending over. Occasional heartburn is common and no cause for alarm. Most people can manage the discomfort of heartburn on their own with lifestyle changes and nonprescription medications. Heartburn that is more frequent or interferes with your daily routine may be a symptom of a more serious condition that requires medical care.
simplified_explanation:
Heartburn is a burning pain in the chest, usually behind the breastbone. It often happens after eating or when lying down and is caused by stomach acid moving up into the esophagus.
Occasional heartburn is common and usually not serious. Most people can manage it with lifestyle changes and over-the-counter medicine.
But if heartburn happens often or interferes with daily life, it could be a sign of a more serious condition and should be checked by a doctor.
plain_explanation: * Heartburn is when you feel a burning pain in your chest. It’s like your heart is being squeezed from the inside out.
symptoms:
- The pain is often worse after eating, especially if you’re eating spicy or greasy foods.
- It can happen in the evening, when you’re trying to sleep.
- Sometimes, it can feel like you have a lump in your throat.
- You may also feel a sour or bitter taste in your mouth.

clinical_description: Idiopathic hypersomnia is a condition that causes people to be very sleepy during the day even after a full night of sleep. People with the condition have trouble waking up from sleep. They also may wake up confused and disoriented. Naps typically don't lead to feeling refreshed. Idiopathic hypersomnia is not common, and the cause of the condition is not known. The need to sleep can strike at any time, including when driving a car or working. This makes idiopathic hypersomnia potentially dangerous. The condition often develops slowly over time. Diagnosing idiopathic hypersomnia requires ruling out more common sleep conditions. Treatment aims to control symptoms with medicine.
simplified_explanation:
Idiopathic hypersomnia is a condition where people feel extremely sleepy during the day, even after getting a full night of sleep. They may also have a hard time waking up and feel confused or groggy.
Naps don’t help, and sleepiness can happen at dangerous times, like while driving. The cause is unknown, and the condition is rare.
It usually develops slowly over time. Doctors diagnose it by ruling out other sleep problems. There’s no cure, but medication can help manage symptoms.
plain_explanation: Idiopathic hypersomnia means that the person has a problem falling asleep or staying asleep at night, and then they still feel very tired during the day.
symptoms:
- They fall asleep easily during the day, even if they're doing something they should be alert for, like driving a car or working.
- They wake up feeling very confused and disoriented.
- They have trouble falling asleep at night.
- They nap a lot, but it doesn't make them feel refreshed.

clinical_description: Indigestion — also called dyspepsia or an upset stomach — is discomfort in your upper abdomen. Indigestion describes certain symptoms, such as belly pain and a feeling of fullness soon after you start eating, rather than a specific disease. Indigestion can also be a symptom of other digestive disorders. Although indigestion is common, each person may experience indigestion in a slightly different way. Symptoms of indigestion may be felt occasionally or as often as daily. Indigestion may often be relieved with lifestyle changes and medicines.
simplified_explanation:
Indigestion, also called dyspepsia or an upset stomach, is discomfort in the upper belly. It might feel like pain, bloating, or getting full too fast while eating.
It’s a common problem and can happen once in a while or more often. Some people feel it daily, while others only get it occasionally.
Indigestion can be caused by food, stress, or other medical problems. It’s often managed with diet changes, stress management, and medicine.
plain_explanation: Indigestion is when your stomach feels uncomfortable and doesn't work properly. It's like when you have a bad stomach ache after eating too much food. Indigestion isn't a disease, but it can be a symptom of other problems with your digestive system. Everyone's indigestion is a little bit different, but some people might feel a burning pain in their belly, or a fullness that comes on quickly after eating. Indigestion can often be fixed with changes to your diet and lifestyle, or with medicine.
symptoms:
- Belly pain: A feeling of pain or discomfort in your stomach area.
- Fullness soon after eating: Feeling full or uncomfortable soon after you start eating.
- Burping or bloating: Gas or air bubbles in your stomach that make you burp or feel bloated.
- Nausea or vomiting: Feeling sick or throwing up after eating.

clinical_description: Keratoconus (ker-uh-toe-KOH-nus) is an eye condition in which the clear, dome-shaped front of the eye, called the cornea, gets thinner, steeper and bulges outward into a cone shape. A cone-shaped cornea causes blurred vision and may cause sensitivity to light and glare. Keratoconus usually affects both eyes. However, it can affect one eye more than the other. It generally begins to affect people between the late teens and 30 years of age. The condition may progress slowly for 10 years or longer. In the early stages of keratoconus, you might be able to correct vision problems with glasses or soft contact lenses. Later, you may have to be fitted with rigid, gas permeable contact lenses or other types of lenses, such as scleral lenses. If your condition gets worse, you may need a cornea transplant. A procedure called corneal collagen cross-linking may help to slow or stop keratoconus from progressing, possibly preventing the need for a future cornea transplant. This treatment may be offered in addition to the vision correction options above.
simplified_explanation:
Keratoconus is an eye condition where the front part of the eye, called the cornea, becomes thin and bulges into a cone shape. This causes blurry vision and sensitivity to light.
It usually starts between the late teens and early 30s and may get worse over 10 years or more. Glasses or soft lenses may help early on, but many people need special hard lenses as the condition gets worse.
In more serious cases, a cornea transplant may be needed. A procedure called corneal cross-linking can also help slow or stop the condition from getting worse.
plain_explanation:
---

 Keratoconus is when the clear, dome-shaped part of your eye gets thinner and flatter, and can't see well. It's like a mushroom on your eye that's too big.
symptoms:
- Blurry vision
- Double vision
- Light sensitivity
- Glare sensitivity

clinical_description: Klinefelter syndrome is a common condition that results when a person assigned male at birth has an extra copy of the X sex chromosome instead of the typical XY. Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic condition that occurs before birth, but it often isn't diagnosed until adulthood. Klinefelter syndrome may affect testicular growth. This results in smaller testicles, which can lead to making less of the hormone testosterone. The syndrome also may cause smaller muscle mass, less body and facial hair, and extra breast tissue. The effects of Klinefelter syndrome vary, and not everyone has the same symptoms. Most people with Klinefelter syndrome produce little or no sperm, but assisted reproductive procedures may make it possible for some people with Klinefelter syndrome to have biological children.
simplified_explanation:
Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic condition that happens when someone assigned male at birth has an extra X chromosome. This affects how the body grows and develops, especially in puberty. It may cause smaller testicles, lower testosterone levels, and changes like less facial hair or more breast tissue.
Not everyone with Klinefelter syndrome has the same symptoms. It’s often not diagnosed until adulthood.
Many people with this condition have low or no sperm, but fertility treatments may help some have biological children. Support and hormone therapy can help with symptoms.
plain_explanation: Klinefelter syndrome is when a boy is born with one extra X chromosome instead of two XY chromosomes. This can happen before birth and may not be found out until a person grows up.
symptoms:
- Smaller testicles
- Less testosterone, which can cause less muscle mass and hair
- Extra breast tissue
- Less sperm production, but assisted reproductive procedures can make it possible to have kids

clinical_description: Laryngitis is an inflammation of your voice box (larynx) from overuse, irritation or infection. Inside the larynx are your vocal cords — two folds of mucous membrane covering muscle and cartilage. Normally, your vocal cords open and close smoothly, forming sounds through their movement and vibration. How speech occurs Speech occurs when air flows from the lungs, up the windpipe (trachea) and through the voice box (larynx). This causes the vocal cords to vibrate, creating sound. Sound is shaped into words by the muscles controlling the soft palate, tongue and lips. Vocal cords open and closed Vocal cords open when you breathe and then close to produce sound when vibrating together. But with laryngitis, your vocal cords become inflamed or irritated. This makes the vocal cords swell, which distorts the sounds produced by air passing over them. As a result, your voice sounds hoarse. In some cases of laryngitis, your voice can become almost undetectable. Laryngitis may be short-lived (acute) or long lasting (chronic). Most cases of laryngitis are triggered by a temporary viral infection and aren't serious. Persistent hoarseness can sometimes signal a more serious underlying medical condition.
simplified_explanation:
Laryngitis is when the voice box (larynx) gets swollen, usually from overuse, a cold, or irritation. The vocal cords inside the larynx help you speak by vibrating when air passes over them. When they’re swollen, your voice may sound hoarse or even disappear.
Laryngitis can be short-term (from a virus) or long-lasting (from smoking or overuse). Most cases go away on their own in a few days.
If hoarseness lasts a long time, it could be a sign of another problem and should be checked by a doctor.
plain_explanation:
---

 Laryngitis is when your voice box (larynx) gets inflamed or irritated. This can happen because you talk too much, smoke, or get a virus. It can also happen because of allergies or cancer.
symptoms:
- **Hoarse voice:** Your voice may sound rough or strained when you talk.
- **Noise or pain when swallowing:** You might hear a strange noise or feel pain when you swallow.
- **Cough:** A dry, persistent cough is common with laryngitis.
- **Sore throat:** Your throat might feel sore or scratchy.

clinical_description: Leukemia is cancer of the body's blood-forming tissues, including the bone marrow and the lymphatic system. Many types of leukemia exist. Some forms of leukemia are more common in children. Other forms of leukemia occur mostly in adults. Leukemia usually involves the white blood cells. Your white blood cells are potent infection fighters — they normally grow and divide in an orderly way, as your body needs them. But in people with leukemia, the bone marrow produces an excessive amount of abnormal white blood cells, which don't function properly. Treatment for leukemia can be complex — depending on the type of leukemia and other factors. But there are strategies and resources that can help make your treatment successful.
simplified_explanation:
Leukemia is a type of cancer that affects how your body makes blood, especially white blood cells. In leukemia, the body makes too many abnormal white blood cells that don’t work the way they should.
There are different types, some more common in children and others in adults.
Symptoms and treatments can vary, but care usually involves medications, chemotherapy, and sometimes bone marrow transplants. With the right treatment, many people live full lives.
plain_explanation: Leukemia is a kind of cancer that happens when your body makes too many of a type of white blood cells. These cells don't work right and can't fight infections well. Leukemia can happen to people of all ages, but it's more common in kids.
symptoms:
- Feeling very tired all the time
- Bleeding easily, like from your nose or gums
- Infections that seem to come back quickly
- Pain in your bones or joints

Remember, if you're feeling sick or worried about your health, it's important to talk to a doctor. They can help you understand what's happening in your body and come up with a plan to make you feel better.

Term: Asthma
Description: Asthma is a lung condition that causes symptoms like wheezing, coughing, and difficulty breathing. It can happen when your airways get narrow, which makes it harder for you to breathe air in and out. Asthma is a chronic condition, meaning it lasts for a long time. It can be caused by different things, like allergens or irritants in the air. There are different types of asthma, and each person's experience with it can be different.

clinical_description: Malaria is a disease caused by a parasite. The parasite is spread to humans through the bites of infected mosquitoes. People who have malaria usually feel very sick with a high fever and shaking chills. While the disease is uncommon in temperate climates, malaria is still common in tropical and subtropical countries. Each year nearly 290 million people are infected with malaria, and more than 400,000 people die of the disease. To reduce malaria infections, world health programs distribute preventive drugs and insecticide-treated bed nets to protect people from mosquito bites. The World Health Organization has recommended a malaria vaccine for use in children who live in countries with high numbers of malaria cases. Protective clothing, bed nets and insecticides can protect you while traveling. You also can take preventive medicine before, during and after a trip to a high-risk area. Many malaria parasites have developed resistance to common drugs used to treat the disease.
simplified_explanation:
Malaria is a serious disease caused by a parasite that spreads through the bite of an infected mosquito. It causes high fever, chills, and feeling very sick.
Malaria is rare in places like the U.S. but still common in many tropical countries. Every year, hundreds of thousands of people die from it.
You can help prevent malaria by using bug spray, bed nets, and taking preventive medicine when traveling to high-risk areas. There’s also a vaccine for young children in high-risk regions. Treatment is available, but some forms of malaria are harder to treat due to drug resistance.
plain_explanation: Malaria is a sickness that can happen if a tiny bug called a parasite gets into your body. This happens when you get bitten by a mosquito that has the parasite on it. Most people who get malaria feel very sick, with a high fever and shaking chills. There are many ways to prevent malaria, like taking medicine and using bed nets with insecticide. The World Health Organization has a special vaccine to protect against malaria.
symptoms:
- Fever
- Chills and shaking
- Headache
- Muscle pain
- Nausea and vomiting

clinical_description: Measles, also called rubeola, was once a common childhood illness. It's caused by a virus that spreads easily through the air and settles on surfaces. A vaccine can prevent measles infection. Most people recover from measles in about 10 days. It usually doesn't cause long-term medical issues. But measles can be serious and even deadly. This is especially true for children younger than age 5 and people with severely weakened immune systems. Measles is treated by managing symptoms and preventing complications. Get a measles vaccine when recommended to keep the virus from spreading. Because of vaccination, measles hasn't been common in the United States for more than two decades. Often, measles cases in the U.S. come from outside the country. Outbreaks are more common among people who are not vaccinated. Measles illness causes a blotchy rash. It may be shades of red, purple or brown depending on your skin color. The rash most often shows up first on the face and behind the ears. The rash then spreads to the chest and back and finally to the feet.
simplified_explanation:
Measles is a viral infection that spreads easily through the air and on surfaces. It usually starts with a fever and cough, followed by a blotchy rash that spreads from the face to the rest of the body.
Most people recover in about 10 days, but it can be dangerous — especially for young children and people with weak immune systems.
There is no cure, but symptoms can be managed. The measles vaccine is very effective at preventing the disease and has made it rare in many countries. Outbreaks mostly happen in areas with low vaccination rates.
plain_explanation:
---

 Measles is a sickness that used to happen a lot when kids were young. It's caused by a virus that spreads through the air or settles on surfaces. But now, thanks to a vaccine, most people don't get measles anymore.
symptoms:
- Measles starts with a high fever, usually above 104°F.
- You might also get a bad cough, runny nose, and sore throat.
- Red, watery eyes are also common.
- Finally, a rash of tiny, red spots usually appears on your face and neck, then spreads down your body.

clinical_description: Nearsightedness is a common vision condition in which close objects look clear but far objects look blurry. The medical term for nearsightedness is myopia. Myopia happens when the shape of the eye — or the shape of certain parts of the eye — causes light rays to bend or refract. Light rays that should be focused on nerve tissues at the back of the eye, called the retina, are focused in front of the retina instead. Nearsightedness usually develops during childhood and adolescence. Typically, it becomes more stable between the ages of 20 and 40. It tends to run in families. A basic eye exam can confirm nearsightedness. You can correct the blurry vision with eyeglasses, contact lenses or refractive surgery.
simplified_explanation:
Nearsightedness, or myopia, is a vision problem where you can see things up close clearly, but things far away look blurry. It happens when the eye’s shape causes light to focus in front of the retina instead of directly on it.
Myopia usually starts in childhood or teenage years and tends to run in families.
It can be diagnosed with a basic eye exam. You can correct it with glasses, contact lenses, or laser surgery.
plain_explanation:
Nearsightedness (Myopia):
You might have heard of this word before! It's when things that are really close up look really clear to you, but things that are farther away look blurry. It's like if you're looking at a book, everything on the book is really clear to you, but everything outside the window is really blurry.
symptoms:
- Blurry vision when looking at things far away from you
- Having to squint or strain to read or see things up close
- Feeling tired or headachy from reading or doing other things that require focusing for a long time
- Difficulty seeing things like street signs or license plates when you're driving

clinical_description: Neuroblastoma is a cancer that starts in cells called neuroblasts. Neuroblasts are immature nerve cells. They are found in several areas of the body. Neuroblastoma most often starts in the neuroblasts in the adrenal glands. The adrenal glands are located on top of each kidney. The glands make hormones that control important functions in the body. Other parts of the body that have neuroblasts and can get neuroblastoma include the spine, belly, chest and neck. Neuroblastoma usually affects children age 5 or younger. Symptoms vary, depending on where it occurs in the body. Some forms of neuroblastoma may go away on their own. Other forms of neuroblastoma need treatment. Treatments include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy and bone marrow transplant. Your child's healthcare team will select the neuroblastoma treatments that are best for your child.
simplified_explanation:
Neuroblastoma is a type of cancer that starts in immature nerve cells called neuroblasts. It usually begins in the adrenal glands, which sit on top of the kidneys, but it can also appear in the chest, belly, spine, or neck.
This cancer mostly affects young children, especially those under age 5. Symptoms depend on where the tumor is in the body.
Some cases go away on their own, but others need treatment, which may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, or a bone marrow transplant. Doctors choose the best treatment plan based on the child’s case.
plain_explanation: Neuroblastoma is a type of cancer that starts in cells called neuroblasts. These are like tiny nerve cells. They're in your body in different places, like your belly, neck, chest, or adrenal glands (which are above your kidneys). Most of the time, it happens to kids under 5 years old. Sometimes it goes away on its own, but sometimes it needs treatment.
symptoms:
- Your child might feel sick to their stomach, with nausea and vomiting (throwing up).
- They may have diarrhea, which is when you have watery poop.
- They might feel very tired and weak, and have trouble breathing.
- They could have a lump or swelling in their neck, belly, chest, or adrenal glands.

This is not an exhaustive list and other symptoms may occur. It's important for your child to see a doctor if they are experiencing any of these symptoms, as neuroblastoma is a serious condition that needs medical attention.

clinical_description: Oligodendroglioma is a growth of cells that starts in the brain or spinal cord. The growth, called a tumor, begins in cells called oligodendrocytes. These cells make a substance that protects nerve cells and helps with the flow of electrical signals in the brain and spinal cord. Oligodendroglioma is most common in adults, but it can happen at any age. Symptoms include seizures, headaches, and weakness or disability in a part of the body. Where this happens in the body depends on which parts of the brain or spinal cord are affected by the tumor. Treatment is with surgery, when possible. Sometimes surgery can't be done if the tumor is in a place that makes it hard to reach with surgical tools. Other treatments may be needed if the tumor can't be removed or if it's likely to come back after surgery.
simplified_explanation:
Oligodendroglioma is a brain or spinal cord tumor that starts in cells called oligodendrocytes. These cells help protect nerve signals in the brain and spinal cord.
This type of tumor is rare and slow-growing, and more common in adults. It can cause seizures, headaches, or weakness depending on where it is in the nervous system.
Treatment often starts with surgery, but if the tumor can’t be safely removed or is likely to come back, radiation or chemotherapy may be used.
plain_explanation: Oligodendroglioma is a kind of brain tumor that starts in cells that make a protective stuff for nerves in your brain or spinal cord. It can happen in anyone, but it's more common in adults. Symptoms can include seizures, headaches, and weakness or trouble moving in one part of your body. The exact place where the tumor happens in your body depends on where the cells that make up the tumor are located. If surgery can be done, it's the best treatment. But if it can't be removed, other treatments might be needed to make sure it doesn't come back.

clinical_description: Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis, affecting millions of people worldwide. It happens when the protective cartilage that cushions the ends of the bones wears down over time. Although osteoarthritis can damage any joint, the condition most commonly affects joints in the hands, knees, hips and spine. Osteoarthritis symptoms can usually be managed, although the damage to joints can't be reversed. Staying active, maintaining a healthy weight and receiving certain treatments might slow progression of the disease and help improve pain and joint function.
simplified_explanation:
Osteoarthritis is the most common type of arthritis. It happens when the cartilage that cushions your joints wears down over time. This can cause pain, stiffness, and make it harder to move.
It often affects the hands, knees, hips, and spine. The damage can’t be reversed, but the symptoms can be managed.
Staying active, keeping a healthy weight, and using medicine or physical therapy can help reduce pain and improve joint movement.
plain_explanation: Osteoarthritis is when the cartilage that protects the ends of bones gets worn down. This can happen to any joint, but it often happens in the hands, knees, hips, and spine.
symptoms:
- Pain or ache in the affected joint
- Stiffness in the joint, making it harder to move or turn
- Swelling in the joint, making it bigger than usual
- Grating or crackling noises when the joint moves

clinical_description: Pancreatitis is inflammation of the pancreas. Inflammation is immune system activity that can cause swelling, pain, and changes in how an organ or tissues work. The pancreas is a long, flat gland that's tucked behind the stomach. The pancreas helps the body digest food and regulates blood sugars. Pancreatitis can be an acute condition. This means it appears suddenly and generally lasts a short time. Chronic pancreatitis is a long-term condition. The damage to the pancreas can get worse over time. Acute pancreatitis may improve on its own. More-serious disease requires treatment in a hospital and can cause life-threatening complications.
simplified_explanation:
Pancreatitis is when the pancreas becomes swollen and painful. The pancreas is a gland behind your stomach that helps digest food and control blood sugar.
It can happen suddenly (acute) or last a long time (chronic). Acute cases may go away on their own, but chronic ones can get worse over time.
Symptoms may include severe belly pain, nausea, and vomiting. Some cases need hospital care, especially if there are serious complications.
plain_explanation: Pancreatitis is when your pancreas gets sick and it gets all red and swollen.
symptoms:
- Belly pain
- It might feel like someone is stabbing you in the stomach.
- Nausea and vomiting
- You might feel sick to your stomach or throw up.
- Diarrhea
- You might have diarrhea (watery poop).

clinical_description: Parkinson's disease is a movement disorder of the nervous system that worsens over time. The nervous system is a network of nerve cells that controls many parts of the body, including movement. Symptoms start slowly. The first symptom may be a barely noticeable tremor in just one hand or sometimes a foot or the jaw. Tremor is common in Parkinson's disease. But the disorder also may cause stiffness, slowing of movement and trouble with balance that raises the risk of falls. In the early stages of Parkinson's disease, your face may show little or no expression. Your arms may not swing when you walk. Your speech may become soft or slurred. Symptoms get worse over time. Although Parkinson's disease can't be cured, medicines may help symptoms get better. Sometimes a healthcare professional may suggest surgery to help control parts of the brain. This surgery may help lessen symptoms.
simplified_explanation:
Parkinson’s disease is a nervous system disorder that affects movement. It usually starts slowly, with symptoms like a tremor in one hand or stiffness in the body.
Over time, it can cause slower movement, poor balance, and changes in speech or facial expression.
There is no cure, but medicines can help reduce symptoms. In some cases, surgery to target brain areas may also help.
plain_explanation: Parkinson's disease is a problem with your brain that makes it hard to move your body. It starts slowly and gets worse over time.
symptoms:
- Tremors (shaking hands, arms, or feet)
- Stiffness
- Slow movement
- Trouble with balance that can cause falls
- Flat face with little or no expression
- Arms not swinging when walking
- Soft or slurred speech

clinical_description: Renal artery stenosis is the narrowing of one or more arteries that carry blood to your kidneys (renal arteries). Narrowing of the arteries prevents enough oxygen-rich blood from reaching your kidneys. Your kidneys need adequate blood flow to help filter waste products and remove excess fluids. Reduced blood flow to your kidneys may injure kidney tissue and increase blood pressure throughout your body.
simplified_explanation:
Renal artery stenosis is when the arteries that bring blood to your kidneys become too narrow. This means the kidneys don’t get enough blood and can’t work properly.
It can lead to kidney damage and high blood pressure. If not treated, the kidneys can become injured.
Treatment may involve medications, lifestyle changes, or sometimes procedures to open the narrowed arteries.
plain_explanation: This condition happens when the arteries that bring blood to your kidneys get narrower. It's like if the main road to your park got blocked by a fallen tree. The tree (or in this case, the blockage) makes it harder for cars to get through.
symptoms:
- High blood pressure
- Severe headaches
- Dizziness or fainting
- Chest pain or shortness of breath.

clinical_description: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) causes infections of the lungs and respiratory tract. It's so common that most children have been infected with the virus by age 2. Respiratory syncytial (sin-SISH-ul) virus can also infect adults. In adults and older, healthy children, RSV symptoms are mild and typically mimic the common cold. Self-care measures are usually all that's needed to relieve any discomfort. RSV can cause severe infection in some people, including babies 12 months and younger (infants), especially premature infants, older adults, people with heart and lung disease, or anyone with a weak immune system (immunocompromised).
simplified_explanation:
RSV is a common virus that causes lung and airway infections. Most kids get it by age 2, and in healthy children or adults, it usually feels like a cold.
But RSV can be dangerous for babies, older adults, and people with heart, lung, or immune problems. It may cause serious breathing issues in these groups.
Most people recover with rest and fluids, but hospital care may be needed for high-risk patients.
plain_explanation: RSV is a type of germ that can make your nose and lungs feel sick. It's like a cold, but it's not the same as the flu. Most kids have had RSV by age 2.
symptoms:
- Runny or stuffy nose
- Coughing
- Sore throat
- Fever
- Wheezing (a high-pitched sound when you breathe in or out)

clinical_description: Sacroiliitis (say-kroe-il-e-I-tis) is a painful condition that affects one or both sacroiliac joints. These joints sit where the lower spine and pelvis meet. Sacroiliitis can cause pain and stiffness in the buttocks or lower back, and the pain might go down one or both legs. Standing or sitting for a long time or climbing stairs can make the pain worse. Sacroiliitis can be hard to diagnose. It can be mistaken for other causes of low back pain. It's been linked to a group of diseases that cause inflammatory arthritis of the spine. Treatment might involve physical therapy and medicines.
simplified_explanation:
Sacroiliitis is when the joints that connect the lower spine and pelvis become inflamed. It can cause pain in the lower back or buttocks, which may spread down the legs.
Pain often gets worse with standing, sitting too long, or climbing stairs. It can be hard to diagnose and is sometimes mistaken for other types of back pain.
It may be related to arthritis in the spine. Physical therapy, medication, and stretching can help reduce pain and improve movement.
plain_explanation: Sacroiliitis is a problem with the sacroiliac joints. These are the places where the spine and pelvis meet. When one or both of these joints get inflamed or irritated, it can cause pain and stiffness in your buttocks or lower back. It might also make your pain worse when you're sitting or standing for a long time or climbing stairs. It can be hard to figure out what's causing your pain, so it might be called sacroiliitis. It's linked to a group of diseases that cause inflammatory arthritis of the spine, like ankylosing spondylitis. Treatment might involve physical therapy and medicine to help relieve your pain.
symptoms:
- Pain in the buttocks or lower back
- Stiffness in the hips or lower back
- Pain when sitting or standing for a long time
- Pain when climbing stairs

clinical_description: Scoliosis is a side-to-side curve of the spine. It's most often diagnosed after age 10 or in the early teen years. The spine can curve to either side and in different parts of the back. Experts don't know the cause of most childhood scoliosis. Most scoliosis is mild. But some curves get worse as children grow. If the curve gets very bad, scoliosis can cause pain and breathing problems. A bad curve of the spine can push on the lungs and make it hard to breathe. Healthcare professionals watch growing children who have mild scoliosis with follow-up visits a few times a year. This most often involves X-rays and a physical exam to see if the curve is getting worse. Many people with scoliosis don't need treatment. Some children may need to wear a brace to stop the curve from getting worse. Others may need surgery to correct the curves.
simplified_explanation:
Scoliosis is when the spine curves sideways, usually in the upper or lower back. It’s most often found in kids or teens after age 10. Many cases are mild, but some curves get worse as a child grows.
If the curve is severe, it can cause pain and even breathing problems by pressing on the lungs.
Doctors usually monitor mild scoliosis with X-rays and checkups. Some children may need to wear a brace to keep the curve from getting worse, and a few may need surgery to straighten the spine.
plain_explanation: Scoliosis: A Scoliosis is when your back curves from side to side. It's most often found after age 10 or when you're a teenager. The spine can curve in different places. Scientists don't know what makes most kids get scoliosis. If the curve gets very big, it can hurt and make breathing harder.
symptoms:
- Back pain
- Shoulder and hip pain
- Breathing problems
- Different size breasts or hips

It's important to remember that not all people with scoliosis need treatment, and some might only need to wear a brace. If you're worried about scoliosis, talk to your doctor!

clinical_description: Tay-Sachs disease is a rare genetic disorder passed from parents to child. It's caused by the absence of an enzyme that helps break down fatty substances. These fatty substances, called gangliosides, build up to toxic levels in the brain and spinal cord and affect the function of the nerve cells. In the most common and severe form of Tay-Sachs disease, signs and symptoms start to show up at about 3 to 6 months of age. As the disease progresses, development slows and muscles begin to weaken. Over time, this leads to seizures, vision and hearing loss, paralysis, and other major issues. Children with this form of Tay-Sachs disease typically live only a few years. Less commonly, some children have the juvenile form of Tay-Sachs disease and may live into their teen years. Rarely, some adults have a late-onset form of Tay-Sachs disease which is often less severe than forms that begin in childhood. If you have a family history of Tay-Sachs disease or if you're a member of a high-risk group and plan to have children, health care providers strongly recommend genetic testing and genetic counseling.
simplified_explanation:
Tay-Sachs is a rare genetic disorder that mostly affects babies. It’s caused by a missing enzyme that normally breaks down fatty substances in the brain and spinal cord. Without it, these substances build up and cause serious brain damage.
Babies with the most common form usually show signs around 3–6 months, including slowed development, muscle weakness, and later, seizures and blindness.
There is no cure, and most children with the severe form live only a few years. There are less severe forms in teens or adults. Genetic testing and counseling are recommended for people at high risk.
plain_explanation: Tay-Sachs disease is a rare genetic disorder that causes the body not to make an enzyme that helps break down fatty substances in the brain and spinal cord. These substances can build up and make the nerves in the brain and spinal cord not work properly. This happens mostly in babies between 3 to 6 months old. As the disease gets worse, babies get weaker and have problems like seizures, vision and hearing loss, and paralysis.
symptoms:
- Muscles get weaker
- Seizures happen
- Vision and hearing get worse
- Paralysis happens

clinical_description: Tetanus is a serious disease of the nervous system caused by a toxin-producing bacterium. The disease causes muscle contractions, particularly of your jaw and neck muscles. Tetanus is commonly known as lockjaw. Severe complications of tetanus can be life-threatening. There's no cure for tetanus. Treatment focuses on managing symptoms and complications until the effects of the tetanus toxin resolve. Because of the widespread use of vaccines, cases of tetanus are rare in the United States and other parts of the developed world. The disease remains a threat to people who aren't up to date on their vaccinations. It's more common in developing countries.
simplified_explanation:
Tetanus is a serious disease caused by a toxin from bacteria. It causes painful muscle tightening, especially in the jaw and neck, which is why it’s often called lockjaw.
It can lead to dangerous complications and even death. There’s no cure, but treatment helps manage symptoms while the body heals.
Tetanus is rare in places with good vaccination programs, but it’s still a threat for people who are not vaccinated. A tetanus shot is the best way to prevent it.
plain_explanation: Tetanus is a really bad infection that makes your muscles tight, especially your jaw and neck muscles. It's called lockjaw because your jaw might lock up and it can be really hard to move. If you get tetanus, you could have some really serious complications that could be deadly. There's no way to cure tetanus, but doctors can help you with your symptoms until your body gets better. It's really important to make sure you have the right vaccinations to prevent tetanus.
symptoms:
- Muscle spasms, especially in the jaw and neck
- Difficulty swallowing
- Rapid heartbeat
- Low blood pressure
- Breathing problems

clinical_description: Ulcerative colitis is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes inflammation and sores, called ulcers, in part of the digestive tract. Ulcerative colitis (UL-sur-uh-tiv koe-LIE-tis) affects the innermost lining of the large intestine, called the colon, and rectum. Symptoms usually develop over time, rather than coming on suddenly. Ulcerative colitis can weaken the body and can sometimes lead to life-threatening complications. While it has no known cure, treatment can greatly reduce and relieve symptoms of the disease. It also may bring about long-term remission.
simplified_explanation:
Ulcerative colitis is a long-term condition that causes inflammation and sores (ulcers) in the large intestine and rectum. It can lead to symptoms like stomach pain, diarrhea, and bleeding.
The disease develops slowly and may have periods where symptoms come and go. It has no cure, but treatments like medicine and diet changes can ease symptoms and prevent flare-ups.
In some cases, it may lead to serious complications and need surgery.
plain_explanation: Ulcerative colitis is when your digestive system gets inflamed. It's like when your skin gets red and itchy from a rash. But instead of on your skin, it happens inside your body in your digestive tract, which is where food travels through to be absorbed into your bloodstream.
symptoms:
- Abdominal pain or cramping
- Diarrhea (frequent or loose bowel movements)
- Loss of appetite or feeling full quickly
- Fatigue (feeling tired easily)

clinical_description: Uveitis is a form of eye inflammation. It affects the middle layer of tissue in the eye wall (uvea). Uveitis (u-vee-I-tis) warning signs often come on suddenly and get worse quickly. They include eye redness, pain and blurred vision. The condition can affect one or both eyes, and it can affect people of all ages, even children. Possible causes of uveitis are infection, injury, or an autoimmune or inflammatory disease. Many times a cause can't be identified. Uveitis can be serious, leading to permanent vision loss. Early diagnosis and treatment are important to prevent complications and preserve your vision.
simplified_explanation:
Uveitis is inflammation inside the eye, affecting the middle layer called the uvea. It often causes redness, eye pain, blurry vision, and can come on suddenly.
It can affect one or both eyes and happen at any age. Uveitis may be caused by infections, injuries, or immune system problems, but sometimes the cause is unknown.
If not treated early, it can lead to permanent vision loss. Quick diagnosis and medications can help prevent damage and protect vision.
plain_explanation: Uveitis is a kind of inflammation inside the eye that can cause problems like redness, pain, and blurry vision. It happens when the middle part of the eye gets swollen.
symptoms:
- Eye pain that comes suddenly and gets worse quickly
- Redness in the whites of the eye
- Blurry vision
- Sensitivity to bright light

clinical_description: Ventricular fibrillation is a type of irregular heart rhythm (arrhythmia). During ventricular fibrillation, the lower heart chambers contract in a very rapid and uncoordinated manner. As a result, the heart doesn't pump blood to the rest of the body. Ventricular fibrillation is an emergency that requires immediate medical attention. It's the most frequent cause of sudden cardiac death. Emergency treatment for ventricular fibrillation includes cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and shocks to the heart with a device called an automated external defibrillator (AED). Medications, implanted devices or surgery may be recommended to prevent episodes of ventricular fibrillation. Ventricular fibrillation may also be called VFib, V-fib or VF.
simplified_explanation:
Ventricular fibrillation is a dangerous heart rhythm problem where the heart’s lower chambers beat fast and out of control. This stops the heart from pumping blood to the body.
It’s a medical emergency and a leading cause of sudden cardiac death.
Immediate treatment includes CPR and shocks to the heart using an AED (defibrillator). Long-term care may include medicines, implanted devices, or surgery to prevent future episodes.
plain_explanation: Ventricular fibrillation is when your heart beats very fast and out of control. It's like when you have a seizure, but with your heart. It happens when your lower heart chambers contract really quickly and can't pump blood to the rest of your body. This is dangerous and requires urgent medical attention.
symptoms:
- You might feel dizzy or lightheaded.
- Your heart might feel fast, pounding, or fluttering.
- You might have trouble breathing or feel short of breath.
- You might pass out.

clinical_description: Vasculitis involves swelling and irritation, called inflammation, of blood vessels. The inflammation can cause the walls of the blood vessels to thicken. This thickening can narrow the vessels. If the narrowing restricts blood flow, it can damage organs and tissues. There are many types of vasculitis. Most of them are rare. Vasculitis might affect just one organ or several. The condition can be short-term or long lasting. Vasculitis can affect anyone. But some types are more common among people in certain age groups. Some types may improve without treatment. Most types need treatment with medicines to control the inflammation and prevent flares.
simplified_explanation:
Vasculitis is when the blood vessels get inflamed, which can cause the walls to thicken and narrow. This reduces blood flow and can damage organs and tissues.
There are many types, and most are rare. Some affect just one area, while others involve many parts of the body.
Symptoms vary, and some forms may improve without treatment. Others need medications to control the immune system and reduce inflammation.
plain_explanation: Vasculitis is when your blood vessels get inflamed, which makes them swell and become tight.
symptoms:
- Fever
- Joint pain and swelling
- Rash on the feet, hands, or ankles
- Fatigue
- Abdominal pain

clinical_description: Whooping cough is an illness that can spread easily. It's also called pertussis. An infection with bacteria causes it. Many people with the illness get a serious hacking cough. Breathing in after coughing often causes a high-pitched noise that sounds like a "whoop." Before the vaccine for pertussis came out, whooping cough was thought of as a childhood disease. Today, whooping cough mainly affects children too young to have gotten all their shots of the vaccine. The illness also tends to affect teenagers and adults whose protection from the vaccine has faded. Deaths linked with whooping cough are rare. Most often, they occur in infants. But pregnant people can help protect their babies by getting a booster shot of the vaccine during pregnancy. Vaccination also is recommended for other people who will have close contact with an infant.
simplified_explanation:
Whooping cough is a bacterial illness that causes a strong cough followed by a high-pitched “whoop” sound when breathing in.
It spreads easily and mostly affects babies and young children, especially if they haven’t had all their vaccines.
Most people recover, but it can be dangerous for infants. A vaccine protects against it, and pregnant people are encouraged to get a booster shot to help protect their newborns.
Vaccination is also important for anyone in close contact with babies.
plain_explanation: Whooping cough is a sickness that can spread easily. It's like a cold or flu, but it's worse. It's caused by a bacteria and it can make people really sick.
symptoms:
- A long, dry cough that sounds like a "whoop" or a "hack"
- Breathing in after coughing often causes a high-pitched noise that sounds like a "whoop"
- Feeling tired and weak
- Losing weight

Whoopsing Cough: An Infection That Can Make You Sick and Spread Easily

Breathing in after coughing often causes a high-pitched noise that sounds like a "whoop." Before the vaccine for pertussis came out, whooping cough was thought of as a childhood disease.
