clinical_description: Wilson's disease is a rare inherited condition that causes copper levels to build up in several organs, especially the liver, brain and eyes. Most people with Wilson's disease are diagnosed between the ages of 5 and 35. But younger and older people can be affected too. Copper plays a key role in building healthy nerves, bones, collagen and the skin pigment melanin. You usually take in copper from the food you eat. Your liver produces a substance called bile that removes any extra copper. But in people with Wilson's disease, copper isn't removed properly and instead builds up. Sometimes it can be life-threatening if it's not treated. When diagnosed early, Wilson's disease is treatable, and many people with the condition live normal lives.
simplified_explanation:
Wilson’s disease is a rare condition that causes too much copper to build up in the body. It mainly affects the liver, brain, and eyes.
Normally, the liver removes extra copper, but in this condition, it doesn’t work properly.
If untreated, copper can build up to dangerous levels and damage organs.
Symptoms can appear anytime between childhood and age 35.
With early diagnosis and proper treatment, people with Wilson’s disease can live normal, healthy lives.
plain_explanation: Wilson's disease is a rare illness where too much copper builds up in the liver, brain, and eyes.
symptoms:
- Difficulty moving or controlling body parts
- Memory problems or confusion
- Red or green skin, hair, or nails
- Eye problems like cataracts or changes in vision

clinical_description: Addison's disease is a rare condition that happens when the body doesn't make enough of some hormones. Another name for Addison's disease is primary adrenal insufficiency. With Addison's disease, the adrenal glands make too little of the hormone cortisol. Often, they also make too little of another hormone called aldosterone. Damage to the adrenal glands causes Addison's disease. Symptoms can start slowly. Early symptoms may include extreme tiredness, salt cravings and weight loss. Addison's disease can affect anyone. Without treatment, it can be life-threatening. Treatment involves taking lab-made hormones to replace those that are missing.
simplified_explanation:
Addison’s disease happens when the body doesn’t make enough important hormones, like cortisol and aldosterone.
These hormones help control energy, blood pressure, and the balance of salt and water.
Early symptoms can include extreme tiredness, weight loss, and craving salty foods.
Without treatment, the condition can be life-threatening, but it’s manageable by taking hormone replacement medicine every day.
plain_explanation: Addison's disease is when the body doesn't make enough of some important chemicals called hormones. These hormones come from small glands called adrenal glands, which are like small walnuts sitting on top of your kidneys. The adrenal glands make a hormone called cortisol that helps the body use energy, and another hormone called aldosterone that helps the body use salt. Without enough of these hormones, the body doesn't work right.
symptoms:
- Extreme tiredness or weakness that doesn't go away, even after getting a good night's sleep
- Weight loss, despite eating normally
- Salt cravings, which means the person might eat a lot of salt-rich foods or drinks, like popcorn or chips
- Frequent urination, thirst, or both, which can be a sign of the body losing too much salt

Note: These symptoms can start slowly and may be hard to spot. If you're worried about any symptoms you're having, it's important to talk to a doctor.

clinical_description: A Baker cyst is a fluid-filled growth behind the knee. It causes a bulge and a feeling of tightness. Also called a popliteal (pop-luh-TEE-ul) cyst, a Baker cyst sometime causes pain. The pain can get worse when with activity or when fully straightening or bending the knee. A Baker cyst is usually the result of a problem with the knee joint, such as arthritis or a cartilage tear. Both conditions can cause the knee to produce too much fluid. Although a Baker cyst may cause swelling and discomfort, treating the underlying problem that is causing it usually provides relief.
simplified_explanation:
A Baker cyst is a fluid-filled lump that forms behind the knee. It can cause tightness, swelling, and pain, especially when bending or straightening the leg.
It often happens when there’s a problem inside the knee, like arthritis or a torn cartilage.
The cyst is not dangerous, and many go away on their own.
Treating the underlying knee problem usually helps the cyst shrink or disappear.
plain_explanation:
1. A Baker cyst is like a big lump on your knee that makes it feel tight. It's called a "popliteal cyst," but we call it a "Baker cyst" because Dr. James Baker discovered it! It happens when there's too much fluid in the knee joint, like when you're swimming in a pool, and your knee just keeps going up and down! The fluid in the cyst can be painful, and it can make your knee feel tight and uncomfortable.
2.
symptoms:
- Pain or discomfort in the knee
- A tight or bulging feeling in the back of the knee
- Difficulty straightening or bending the knee
- Swelling or tenderness in the knee

Term: Sinusitis
Description: Sinusitis (also called sinus inflammation or sinus infection) happens when the lining of the sinuses (small air-filled spaces in the skull) becomes inflamed or infected. This can happen because of a cold, an allergic reaction, or a bacterial or fungal infection. Symptoms of sinusitis include congestion, runny nose, facial pain, and headaches. Sinusitis is usually mild, but in some cases, it can be severe or last for a long time

clinical_description: Cerebral palsy is a group of conditions that affect movement and posture. It's caused by damage that occurs to the developing brain, most often before birth. Symptoms appear during infancy or preschool years and vary from very mild to serious. Children with cerebral palsy may have exaggerated reflexes. The arms, legs and trunk may appear floppy. Or they may have stiff muscles, known as spasticity. Symptoms also can include irregular posture, movements that can't be controlled, a walk that's not steady or some combination of these. Cerebral palsy may make it hard to swallow. It also can cause eye muscle imbalance, in which the eyes don't focus on the same object. People with the condition might have reduced range of motion in their joints due to muscle stiffness. The cause of cerebral palsy and its effect on function vary from person to person. Some people with cerebral palsy can walk while others need assistance. Some people have intellectual disabilities, but others do not. Epilepsy, blindness or deafness also might affect some people with cerebral palsy. There is no cure, but treatments can help improve function. The symptoms of cerebral palsy may vary during the child's development, but the condition doesn't get worse. The condition generally stays the same over time.
simplified_explanation:
Cerebral palsy is a group of conditions that affect movement, posture, and muscle control.
It happens when the brain is damaged early in life — often before birth.
Symptoms can range from mild to serious and may include stiff or floppy muscles, trouble walking, or uncontrolled movements.
Some people may also have trouble speaking, seeing, or learning, but not everyone.
There’s no cure, but treatments like physical therapy and support can help improve everyday life.
plain_explanation: Cerebral palsy is when your brain doesn't work the way it should, and it can affect how you move and stand.
symptoms:
- You might have trouble walking or standing straight.
- Your arms or legs might feel floppy or too stiff.
- Your eyes might not focus on the same thing.
- You might have trouble swallowing.

clinical_description: Diverticulitis is inflammation of irregular bulging pouches in the wall of the large intestine. Typically, the wall of the large intestine, also called the colon, is smooth. An irregular, bulging pouch in the colon wall is called a diverticulum. Multiple pouches are called diverticula. Diverticula are common, especially after age 50. They are usually found in the lower part of the colon. Most often, they don't cause problems. The presence of diverticula is called diverticulosis. Diverticulosis isn't a disease condition. When these pouches become inflamed, the condition is called diverticulitis. Inflammation is immune system activity that increases blood flow and fluids to a site in the body and delivers disease-fighting cells. Inflammation of diverticula can cause severe pain, fever, nausea and changes in your stool habits. Mild diverticulitis is usually treated with rest, changes in your diet and possibly antibiotics. Severe diverticulitis usually needs antibiotic treatment in the hospital. Surgery may be needed for severe or frequent diverticulitis.
simplified_explanation:
Diverticulitis is when small bulging pouches in the wall of the colon (large intestine) become inflamed or infected.
These pouches are called diverticula and are common in people over 50.
When they get inflamed, it can cause severe belly pain, fever, and nausea.
Mild cases can often be treated with rest, diet changes, and sometimes antibiotics.
Severe cases may require hospital care or even surgery.
plain_explanation: Diverticulitis is when the pouches in your colon (large intestine) get inflamed. These pouches are usually fine and don't cause problems. But sometimes they can get sick and cause pain, fever, and changes in your poop.
symptoms:
- Severe belly or abdominal pain
- Fever
- Nausea (feeling sick)
- Changes in your poop (like diarrhea or constipation)

clinical_description: Edema is swelling caused by too much fluid trapped in the body's tissues. Edema can affect any part of the body. But it's more likely to show up in the legs and feet. Medicines and pregnancy can cause edema. It also can be the result of a disease, such as congestive heart failure, kidney disease, venous insufficiency or cirrhosis of the liver. Wearing compression garments and reducing salt in the diet often relieves edema. When a disease causes edema, the disease needs treatment, as well.
simplified_explanation:
Edema is swelling caused by extra fluid getting trapped in the body’s tissues, often in the legs or feet.
It can happen from medicines, pregnancy, or health conditions like heart or kidney problems.
Wearing compression socks and eating less salt can help.
When a disease causes edema, the disease needs specific treatment to control it.
plain_explanation: Edema means swelling in the body. It happens when too much fluid gets stuck in the tissues. This can happen in many places, but it often happens in the legs and feet. There are different ways to get edema. It can happen because of medicine, pregnancy, or a health problem like heart disease or kidney disease.
symptoms:
- Legs feel heavy or achy
- Feet feel swollen or puffy
- Clothing feels tight around the ankles and knees
- Fluid might collect in the ankles and feet, making it hard to walk.

clinical_description: Ganglion cysts are lumps that most often appear along the tendons or joints of wrists or hands. They also can occur in ankles and feet. Ganglion cysts are typically round or oval and are filled with a jellylike fluid. They are not cancer. Small ganglion cysts can be pea-sized. They can change size. Ganglion cysts can be painful if they press on a nearby nerve. Sometimes they affect joint movement. For a ganglion cyst that causes problems, having a health care provider drain the cyst with a needle might be an option. So might removing the cyst surgically. But if there are no symptoms, no treatment is necessary. Often, the cysts grow and shrink. Some go away on their own.
simplified_explanation:
Ganglion cysts are non-cancerous lumps that usually appear near joints or tendons, especially in the hands or wrists.
They’re filled with a jelly-like fluid and can change size or go away on their own.
Sometimes they hurt if they press on a nerve or get in the way of joint movement.
If the cyst causes pain or problems, it can be drained or removed.
If there are no symptoms, it often doesn’t need treatment.
plain_explanation: Ganglion cysts are like tiny lumps that can show up on your hands or wrists. They're usually round or oval and filled with a jelly-like fluid. They don't cause cancer, but they can be uncomfortable if they press on nerves. Sometimes they can make joints move a little less smoothly. Sometimes the cysts will go away on their own or shrink, and sometimes they'll grow bigger. If you see a cyst that's causing problems, your doctor might drain the fluid from it with a needle or remove it with surgery. But if there are no symptoms, no treatment is needed.
symptoms:
- The cyst may feel like a lump under your skin.
- It may ache or feel uncomfortable.
- It might make your hand or wrist feel stiff.
- The cyst might press on nerves and cause tingling or numbness in your hand or fingers.

clinical_description: Meningitis is an infection and swelling, called inflammation, of the fluid and membranes around the brain and spinal cord. These membranes are called meninges. The inflammation from meningitis most often triggers symptoms such as headache, fever and a stiff neck. Viral infections are the most common cause of meningitis in the United States. Bacteria, parasites and fungi also can cause it. Sometimes meningitis improves in a few weeks without treatment. But meningitis also can cause death. It often needs quick treatment with antibiotics. Seek medical care right away if you think that you or someone in your family has meningitis. For meningitis caused by bacteria, early treatment can prevent serious complications.
simplified_explanation:
Meningitis is an infection that causes swelling around the brain and spinal cord.
This swelling is called inflammation and can cause fever, headache, and a stiff neck.
It can be caused by viruses, bacteria, or fungi.
Some mild cases go away on their own, but bacterial meningitis can be deadly and needs immediate treatment with antibiotics.
If you think someone might have meningitis, it’s important to get medical help right away.
plain_explanation: Meningitis happens when there's a problem with the fluid and membranes around the brain and spinal cord. This can make people feel really sick.
symptoms:
- Headache
- Fever
- A stiff neck
- Difficulty walking or talking (rare but possible)

clinical_description: Plantar fasciitis (PLAN-tur fas-e-I-tis) is one of the most common causes of heel pain. It involves inflammation of a thick band of tissue that runs across the bottom of each foot and connects the heel bone to the toes, known as the plantar fascia. Plantar fasciitis commonly causes stabbing pain that often occurs with your first steps in the morning. As you get up and move, the pain normally decreases, but it might return after long periods of standing or when you stand up after sitting. The cause of plantar fasciitis is poorly understood. It is more common in runners and in people who are overweight.
simplified_explanation:
Plantar fasciitis is a common cause of heel pain. It happens when a thick band of tissue along the bottom of your foot, called the plantar fascia, gets inflamed.
The pain often feels sharp and is worst with your first steps in the morning.
It may get better during the day, but it can return after sitting or standing for a long time.
It’s more common in runners and people who are overweight.
Treatments include rest, stretching, special shoes, or other therapies.
plain_explanation: Plantar fasciitis is when your foot hurts on the bottom because the band of tissue that connects your heel bone to your toes gets inflamed.
symptoms:
- Pain on the bottom of your heel that hurts when you first get up in the morning and can return later in the day.
- Pain when you stand up after sitting or after a long period of standing.
- Pain on the bottom of your heel when you run.
- Pain on the bottom of your heel when you walk on tiptoes.
